(Sorry for spamming, but I wanted to head off the inevitable reply...)

I looked deeper and found the notes about starting each SURT prefix line
with a "+"  This didn't seem to have any effect on the scoping, but it
did get rid of the non-LDH errors.

Also, before anyone asks, here are a few of the URLs that were
(erroneously) crawled.  Let me know if I'm wrong about that:

http://www.technicalcollegesystemofgeorgia.org/
http://gov.georgia.gov/02/gov/home/0,2218,78006749,00.html

Obviously, I think these should be excluded by the surt prefix:
http://(org,georgiaencyclopedia,www,)/nge/about/

Thanks,
Micah

Micah Wedemeyer wrote:
> 
> 
> Still having trouble here...
> 
> I've tried adding the SURT prefixes to the seeds file, and it doesn't
> seem to limit the crawl scope. In addition, I see the following in the
> heritrix output log:
> 
> Mar 5, 2008 5:29:54 PM org.archive.modules.seeds.SeedFileIterator transform
> INFO: line in seed file ignored: gnu.inet.encoding.IDNAException:
> Contains non-LDH characters. (org,georgiaencyclopedia,www,)
> org.apache.commons.httpclient.URIException:
> gnu.inet.encoding.IDNAException: Contains non-LDH characters.
> (org,georgiaencyclopedia,www,)
> 
> Here is a snippet of my global.sheet:
> 
> root:scope:rules=list, org.archive.modules.deciderules.DecideRule
> root:scope:rules:0=object, org.archive.modules.deciderules.RejectDecideRule
> root:scope:rules:1=object,
> org.archive.modules.deciderules.surt.SurtPrefixedDecideRule
> root:scope:rules:1:rebuild-on-reconfig=boolean, true
> root:scope:rules:1:seeds-as-surt-prefixes=boolean, true
> root:scope:rules:2=object,
> org.archive.modules.deciderules.TooManyHopsDecideRule
> root:scope:rules:3=object,
> org.archive.modules.deciderules.TransclusionDecideRule
> root:scope:rules:4=object,
> org.archive.modules.deciderules.PathologicalPathDecideRule
> root:scope:rules:5=object,
> org.archive.modules.deciderules.TooManyPathSegmentsDecideRule
> root:scope:rules:6=object,
> org.archive.modules.deciderules.PrerequisiteAcceptDecideRule
> 
> The contents of the seeds file are as follows:
> 
> http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/about/Index.jsp
> <http://www.georgiaencyclopedia.org/nge/about/Index.jsp>
> http://(org,georgiaencyclopedia,www,)/nge/about/
> 
> I've also tried the SURTS_SOURCE_FILE, but it (seems to) try to infer
> the surt prefix, and I want to specify it exactly.
> 
> What am I doing wrong?
> 
> Thanks,
> Micah
> 
> Micah Wedemeyer wrote:
>>
>>
>> I'd like to be able to crawl with the following 4 filters:
>>
>> 1 - Crawl by path (ie. http://sub.example.com/foo/
> <http://sub.example.com/foo/>
>> <http://sub.example.com/foo/ <http://sub.example.com/foo/>> )
>> 2 - Crawl by host (ie. http://sub.example.com <http://sub.example.com>
> <http://sub.example.com <http://sub.example.com>> )
>> 3 - Crawl by domain (ie. http://*.example.com <http://*.example.com>
> <http://*.example.com <http://*.example.com>> )
>> 4 - Free (crawl whatever you find)
>>
>> Now, it seems that the SurtPrefixedDecideRule should be able to handle
>> all these cases. I'm just unclear on how to go from a seed to the
>> correct surt prefix.
>>
>> Assume we have a seed of: http://sub.example.com/foo/index.html
> <http://sub.example.com/foo/index.html>
>> <http://sub.example.com/foo/index.html
> <http://sub.example.com/foo/index.html>>
>>
>> Its surt form would be: http://(com, example, sub,)/foo/index.html
>>
>> Are these surt prefixes correct for their respective cases?:
>>
>> 1 - http://(com, example, sub,)/foo/
>> 2 - http://(com, example, sub,
>> 3 - http://(com, example
>> 4 - http://
>>
>> Please tell me if I have something wrong there.
>>
>> Assuming I understand that correctly, I'm unclear on how to configure
>> the SurtPrefixedDecideRule module. Specifically, how can I specify a
>> particular surt prefix? I'm assuming that the prefix inferred from the
>> seed is the most restrictive (ie. it will always be case 1 in my list
>> above). So, I would like to be able to explicitly set the prefix set.
>> I notice there's an option to do this from a file, but can it also be
>> done programmatically? Can I specify it directly?
>>
>> Alternately, it looks like I could add the specific surt prefix to the
>> seed file, and then set SEEDS_AS_SURT_PREFIXES to true. However, the
>> surt prefix in the seeds file would not be a valid URI. Is that a
>> problem, to have invalid URIs in the seeds file?
>>
>> To sum up, the basic questions are this: do I understand surt prefixes
>> correctly, and if so, how do I explicitly specify the desired prefiexs
>> to the SurtPrefixedDecideRule?
>>
>> Thanks,
>> Micah
